articles.headline: High-End Retailers Offering More Discounts
articles.snippet: As the recession drags on, luxury retailers’ secret sales, once kept for the stores’ best customers, have spread.
articles.abstract: As the recession drags on, luxury retailers’ secret sales, once kept for the stores’ best customers, have spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scott Stuart was at the Bloomingdale’s store in Manhattan when a salesman sidled up to him, said a private sale was under way and offered him a discount on the slacks he was inspecting.

articles.headline: With Boots in Iraq, Minds Drift to Afghanistan
articles.snippet: There are still some 130,000 U.S. troops in Iraq, but the war in Iraq is no longer the center of the action for the Pentagon.
articles.abstract: There are still some 130,000 U.S. troops in Iraq, but the war in Iraq is no longer the center of the action for the Pentagon.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLIL AIR BASE, Iraq  In this desert brush land where the occupiers and occupied are moving into an uneasy new partnership, American and Iraqi commanders sat side by side earlier this week and described their biggest problems to Robert M. Gates, the visiting defense secretary.

articles.headline: Dealers Welcome Clunker Traffic, Even if It’s No Cure-All
articles.snippet: Analysts said the jump in July vehicle sales will be significant, but perhaps temporary.
articles.abstract: Analysts said the jump in July vehicle sales will be significant, but perhaps temporary.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  It had been a dismal July in dealer showrooms  as bad as every month so far this year.

articles.headline: Conspiracy Trial for 100 Dissidents Begins in Iran
articles.snippet: The Iranian authorities opened an extraordinary mass trial against more than 100 opposition figures.
articles.abstract: The Iranian authorities opened an extraordinary mass trial against more than 100 opposition figures.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Iranian authorities opened an extraordinary mass trial against more than 100 opposition figures on Saturday, accusing them of conspiring with foreign powers to stage a revolution through terrorism, subversion, and a media campaign to discredit last month’s presidential election.
articles.byline: By Robert F. Worth and Nazila Fathi

articles.headline: TV Contestants: Tired, Tipsy and Pushed to Brink
articles.snippet: Grueling conditions are largely the rule for reality shows like “Project Runway” and “Hell’s Kitchen.”
articles.abstract: Grueling conditions are largely the rule for reality shows like “Project Runway” and “Hell’s Kitchen.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  In the first episode of this season’s “Hell’s Kitchen,” the 16 aspiring chefs clamber out of a bus and canter into the kitchen of Gordon Ramsay’s reality show restaurant like convicts on a jailbreak. If the current season is like earlier ones, that is not so far from the truth.

articles.headline: $100 Million Payday Poses Problem for Pay Czar
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department’s executive pay czar will have to answer a $100 million question: Should Andrew J. Hall get to collect his bonus?
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department’s executive pay czar will have to answer a $100 million question: Should Andrew J. Hall get to collect his bonus?
articles.lead_paragraph: In a few weeks, the Treasury Department’s czar of executive pay will have to answer this $100 million question: Should Andrew J. Hall get his bonus?

articles.headline: Halted ’03 Iraq Plan Illustrates U.S. Fear of Cyberwar Risk
articles.snippet: Fears of collateral damage are shaping an effort to develop rules and tactics for carrying out attacks on computer networks.
articles.abstract: Fears of collateral damage are shaping an effort to develop rules and tactics for carrying out attacks on computer networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: It would have been the most far-reaching case of computer sabotage in history. In 2003, the Pentagon and American intelligence agencies made plans for a cyberattack to freeze billions of dollars in the bank accounts of Saddam Hussein and cripple his government’s financial system before the United States invaded Iraq. He would have no money for war supplies. No money to pay troops.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Give BB&T Liberty, but Not a Bailout
articles.snippet: John Allison, chairman of BB&T, leads his company with an Ayn Randian “commitment to reason.” To him, the government’s rush to try to fix the economy is a nightmare come true.
articles.abstract: John Allison, chairman of BB&T, leads his company with an Ayn Randian “commitment to reason.” To him, the government’s rush to try to fix the economy is a nightmare come true.
articles.lead_paragraph: OVER much of the last four decades, John A. Allison IV built BB&T from a local bank in North Carolina into a regional powerhouse that has weathered the economic crisis far better than many of its troubled rivals  largely by avoiding financial gimmickry.

articles.headline: Just When Africa’s Luck Was Changing
articles.snippet: Africa is being affected greatly by the global recession as foreign investment funds are drying up.
articles.abstract: Africa is being affected greatly by the global recession as foreign investment funds are drying up.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIGALI, RWANDA

articles.headline: Investors Without a Lifeline
articles.snippet: Raymond James Financial, one of the nation’s last independent brokerage firms, says buying back auction-rate securities would cost too much.
articles.abstract: Raymond James Financial, one of the nation’s last independent brokerage firms, says buying back auction-rate securities would cost too much.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S time again to revisit the auction-rate securities mess, a nightmare that began 18 months ago but that still hasn’t ended for some unfortunate investors.

articles.headline: Prolonged Aid to Unemployed Is Running Out
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of workers have used up their benefits, and the numbers are expected to soar in the months to come.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of workers have used up their benefits, and the numbers are expected to soar in the months to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the coming months, as many as 1.5 million jobless Americans will exhaust their unemployment insurance benefits, ending what for some has been a last bulwark against foreclosures and destitution.

articles.headline: After Combat, Victims of an Inner War
articles.snippet: The rising toll of suicides in the military has hit a National Guard unit particularly hard: four soldiers, out of roughly 175 members, have committed suicide.
articles.abstract: The rising toll of suicides in the military has hit a National Guard unit particularly hard: four soldiers, out of roughly 175 members, have committed suicide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sgt. Jacob Blaylock flipped on the video camera he had set up in a trailer at the Tallil military base, southeast of Baghdad.

articles.headline: Venezuela Still Aids Colombia Rebels, New Material Shows
articles.snippet: Despite denials by President Hugo Chávez, Venezuelan officials have continued to help Colombia’s largest rebel group, according to new evidence.
articles.abstract: Despite denials by President Hugo Chávez, Venezuelan officials have continued to help Colombia’s largest rebel group, according to new evidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  Despite repeated denials by President Hugo Chávez, Venezuelan officials have continued to assist commanders of Colombia’s largest rebel group, helping them arrange weapons deals in Venezuela and even obtain identity cards to move with ease on Venezuelan soil, according to computer material captured from the rebels in recent months and under review by Western intelligence agencies.

articles.headline: Trying to Heal, Pakistan Valley Fears New Battles
articles.snippet: Beneath the surface of relative calm in Swat, there is the sense that a new and more insidious conflict may be afoot.
articles.abstract: Beneath the surface of relative calm in Swat, there is the sense that a new and more insidious conflict may be afoot.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINGORA, Pakistan  Schools have officially reopened. Soldiers stand guard at checkpoints and have established a semblance of order. Many thousands have returned here to a town that is mostly intact, if still under a military presence.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: 10 Years Ago, an Omen No One Saw
articles.snippet: When Talk magazine was introduced at a decadent party, no one knew what the Internet would do to the business.
articles.abstract: When Talk magazine was introduced at a decadent party, no one knew what the Internet would do to the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ten years ago Sunday, on an island off an island off the coast of America, something impossibly glamorous took place. Partygoers took boats from Manhattan to the home of the Statue of Liberty to plop pashalike on pillows and blankets and munch on lamb chops while Macy Gray sang, their faces illuminated with multicolored Chinese lanterns and fireworks curated and narrated by George Plimpton.

articles.headline: Out of Search Business, Yahoo Shifts Its Focus
articles.snippet: Its search engine now in the hands of Microsoft, Yahoo plans to focus on display ads, content and mobile services.
articles.abstract: Its search engine now in the hands of Microsoft, Yahoo plans to focus on display ads, content and mobile services.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  Carol A. Bartz, chief executive of Yahoo, has been hobbled.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: New Owner for a Magazine as Political Tastes Change
articles.snippet: In June, The Weekly Standard was handed from one conservative billionaire, Rupert Murdoch, to another, Philip F. Anschutz, for about $1 million.
articles.abstract: In June, The Weekly Standard was handed from one conservative billionaire, Rupert Murdoch, to another, Philip F. Anschutz, for about $1 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six years before the invasion of Iraq and four years before the inauguration of George W. Bush, The Weekly Standard, the conservative magazine then owned by Rupert Murdoch, began crafting the intellectual architecture to justify removing Saddam Hussein from power in an essay titled “Saddam Must Go.”

articles.headline: Now on YouTube, Local News
articles.snippet: Nearly 200 news outlets have agreed to post videos on the Web site and split the revenue from ads alongside them.
articles.abstract: Nearly 200 news outlets have agreed to post videos on the Web site and split the revenue from ads alongside them.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its ability to collect articles and sell advertisements against them, Google has already become a huge force in the news business  and the scourge of many newspapers. Now its subsidiary YouTube wants to do the same thing to local television.

articles.headline: Obama Aides See Signs of Recovery but Say It Will Be Slow
articles.snippet: A big unanswered question is whether consumers will increase their savings or support economic growth through spending.
articles.abstract: A big unanswered question is whether consumers will increase their savings or support economic growth through spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s top economic advisers gave upbeat assessments of the American economy on Sunday, predicting an imminent start to a recovery, but a slow and arduous one compared with previous rebounds.

articles.headline: Google Chief Gives Up Board Seat at Apple
articles.snippet: The resignation of Eric E. Schmidt was described as a mutual decision. Regulators say they are still investigating a board overlap between the companies.
articles.abstract: The resignation of Eric E. Schmidt was described as a mutual decision. Regulators say they are still investigating a board overlap between the companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The alliance between Apple and Google, two Silicon Valley giants with a powerful common enemy in Microsoft, is now clearly fraying.
